body: Electron 0.37 is using V8 4.9, it seems that v8-profiler is not compatible with V8 4.9.

Since the directions here: http://electron.atom.io/docs/v0.37.7/tutorial/debugging-main-process/#make-sure-you-have-node-gyp-required-toolsnode-gyp-required-tools-installed don't work, with the current V8 is there anything else we can do to be debugging a crashing electron install?

Asking for myself and so if anyone else finds this issue like I did the answer is posted.

I'm seeing this same error myself after following the [official documentation's steps](http://electron.atom.io/docs/tutorial/debugging-main-process/) and it's blocking me from being able to debug the main process osx 10.10.5 python 2.7.10 make 3.8.1 node 6.2.2 electron 1.3.5 v8-debug 0.7.7 v8-profiler 5.6.5 Also I see that it's trying to retrieve compatible prebuilts from [this S3 url](https://node-inspector.s3.amazonaws.com/profiler/v5.6.5/electron-v1.3-darwin-x64.tar.gz) and regardless of what version combos I put in I'm always seeing something like this: ``` NoSuchKey The specified key does not exist. profiler/v5.6.5/electron-v1.3-darwin-x64.tar.gz 2975A28951E36266 dkt76OTiviZ1s+DyjQDsGwzz3hKry7k0WX8nu7xM8ZMVcytpxB+9doTi58wQjbgc5OTzwlHvSiI= ``` stdout below: ``` node-pre-gyp --target=1.3.5 --runtime=electron --fallback-to-build --directory node_modules/v8-debug/ --dist-url=https://atom.io/download/atom-shell reinstall && node_modules/.bin/node-pre-gyp --target=1.3.5 --runtime=electron --fallback-to-build --directory node_modules/v8-profiler/ --dist-url=https://atom.io/download/atom-shell reinstall [v8-debug] Removing "/Users/username/projectDir/node_modules/v8-debug/build/debug/v0.7.7/electron-v1.3-darwin-x64" node-pre-gyp ERR! Please include the following file with any support request: ```

`v8-profiler` doesn't work with Electron v1.3.0+ due to breaking changes in the V8 API. I've documented a workaround at http://vadim.macagon.com/blog/2016/09/11/rebuilding-node-inspector-for-electron-v13x/ but it's a bit tedious, so I'm contemplating publishing a Node module to make it easier to deal with this.
@enlight having that as an npm module would be really helpful for me
@ejfrancis OK, I've started working on it, I'll let you know when it's ready.
